Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exploiting Sensing Diversity and Conquering Communication Reality to Meet User Requirements in Performance-Critical Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are an important new class of networked systems that integrate sensing, communication, and computation capabilities on a single, inexpensive platform. The significant scale and deep integration with their environments enable WSNs to monitor the physical world and human subjects with an unprecedented spatial and temporal granularity. WSNs designed for performance-critical applications must achieve user requirements on both sensing and communication performance, such as high detection probabilities, low false alarm rates, and bounded time delays and throughputs. Failure to meet these requirements often leads to undesirable or even catastrophic consequences. In a real deployment, both the sensing diversity, i.e., the sensing capability differences among individual sensors or sensor clusters in the deployment, and the lossy, irregular, and heterogeneous WSN communication reality must be addressed. In this project, three research thrusts with seven detailed research tasks are proposed to exploit sensing diversity and conquer communication reality so as to ensure user-requested sensing and communication performance in performance-critical WSNs.

This research will enable meeting performance requirements in a number of critical application domains, including homeland security and surveillance, healthcare and assisted living, natural and physical hazard detection, etc., even when complexity and uncertainty exist in the deployed environment. It will enable psychologists to collect previously unattainable data for advancing their physiological and mental health research. It will also benefit community and health providers for their geriatric driving and aging projects. Benefits to senior residents and local retirement communities will be delivered through collaboration with the Center for Excellence in Aging and Geriatric Health. This project will also be integrated into three courses to expose undergraduate and graduate students to advanced sensor networking and system designs. It will bring students in psychology and students in computer science together to work on applying WSN technologies to physiological and mental health study of older adults. A series of planned week-long day camps and annual open houses will provide hands-on opportunities to a diverse group of minority students and high-schoolers. Distributing the research-based outcomes of this proposal through NCWIT will help increase the number of women in the field of computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to exploit existing sensing diversity and radio irregularity in order to ensure user requested performance in wireless sensor network applications. Research activities were conducted from three aspects: exploiting sensing diversity to ensure sensing performance; ensuring radio-agnostic multi-hop communication performance; and utilizing results of accurate sensing to increase communication efficiency. In total, 46 academic papers have been published based on research results from this NSF project. Data sets such as SignFi and TennisEys were also shared in Github for public access.  Twelve PhD students (two women & one minority), one Master student, four undergraduate students (one women), and one high school student have been trained through this project and contributed to this project. The research results were also integrated into one cross-listed grad/undergrad course and four additional graduate-level courses. Outreach to three local high schools was also conducted through Hackathon for STEM engagement and research dissemination.

In terms of sensing, we exploited sensing diversity to ensure sensing performance. We first characterized sensing diversity among individual sensors, and then exploited sensing diversity in collaboration. We also enabled distributed sensor sharing and collaboration in military surveillance systems and smart health applications. Opportunist sensing resource sharing is also enabled in daily activity recognition scenarios.  

In terms of wireless communication & networking, we ensured performance in radio-agnostic multi-hop communication. With a radio-agnostic media access control abstraction, a range of wireless resources were modeled in a unified way, and monitored and scheduled over multiple hops for specified application performance requirements, including bounded time delay, end-to-end data throughput, and minimized energy consumption. 

We also jointed the research of sensing and wireless communication/networking. On the one hand, this was done through utilizing sensing results to increase communication efficiency. More specifically, we removed unneeded/low priority communication traffic based on accurate sensing results in psychology applications. We also optimized runtime communication settings based on accurate sensing results in these applications. On the other hand, this was also done by directly using wireless communication as a sensor to sense human activities. For example, our SignFi design used a convolutional neural network to model the impact of American Sign Language (ASL) signs on WiFi radio reception, in terms of the radio amplitude and phase changes. While the state of art research can only recognize 25 ASL signs, our research is able to recognize 275 ASL signs, which is one order of magnitude better.
